This is needed for knitr compatibility and fixes issue #45.

This was done before (see pull request #46, commit a019766e8cfb9088f71dcd5aa9b7ab5eb47d094b), but since then, new progress output to STDOUT was added.

I'm testing my branch right now but as all I do is replacing `print` by `cat` and adding `file = stderr()` to those `cat` or `txtProgressBar` calls, I doubt this affects anything else.

title: fix for issue #188
body: Allows AverageExpression() to work even when only one gene is provided. By adding "drop = F" the matrix structure of data.temp is maintained even though it only has one row (default would be for its structure to change from a matrix to a vector), allowing data.temp to be successfully passed as an argument to the apply function.

title: Fix error in AveragePCA() and BuildClusterTree() when using PCA space.
body:
Hi ,

I run into an error when running `BuildClusterTree(object, pcs.use=1:20, ...)` in the PCA space, as previously reported in Issue #137 . 

I fixed the code to make it work. Now it uses the averaged PCA cell embeddings from each cluster to build the tree. Whether the euclidean distance in the PCA space is weighted by eigenvalues depends on the `weight.by.var` argument in `RunPCA()`. 

In addition, there is another error when running `AveragePCA()`:
` number of rows of result is not a multiple of vector length (arg 2)`
This is also fixed in the PR.

title: unquote variable for use in dplyr::gather
body:
Ran into this error when running FeatureHeatmap:

```r
dat <- readRDS("aligned.Rdata")
FeatureHeatmap(dat, features.plot = "XCP1")
Error in FUN(X[[i]], ...) : object 'features.plot' not found
```

Simple 2 character fix, unquoting `features.plot` in the `FeatureHeatmap` function.

Although, this function was working for me previously and I haven't been able to work out what changed in Seurat to produce the error, so someone may want to verify they get the same error when running FeatureHeatmap before merging.

title: Fix error in CalcVarExpRatio
body:
Hi,

I ran into a subscript out of bounds error when running `CalcVarExpRatio` (which calls `CalcLDProj`, where the problem occured). The problem was, when there are missing genes when looking up the gene loadings matrix for a given dimension reduction method, the later selection (`[genes.use,]`) fails, and also causes a later problem when trying to multiply matricies of incorrect shapes. I made a couple of small changes to avoid these problems.

I also added the ability to pass arguments through `RunCCA` to `MergeSeurat`, as I found you sometimes have cell name conflicts and need to specify `add.cell.id`.

Tim

title: Fix subscript out of bounds in FindAllMarkers
body:
Hi, I noticed this error when running FindAllMarkers:

```
Error in genes.de[[i]] : subscript out of bounds
Calls: FindAllMarkers
Execution halted
```

This is due to FindAllMarkers checking if each each entry is null before trying to do something with it, but if the final cluster is null, then nothing gets added to the `genes.de` list. Here's an example:


```r
my_list <- list()
my_list[[1]] <- 1
my_list[[2]] <- NULL
my_list[[3]] <- 3
print(my_list)
```

```
## [[1]]
## [1] 1
## 
## [[2]]
## NULL
## 
## [[3]]
## [1] 3
```

All fine. Now, if the last entry is null:


```r
my_list[[4]] <- NULL
print(my_list)
```

```
## [[1]]
## [1] 1
## 
## [[2]]
## NULL
## 
## [[3]]
## [1] 3
```

There's no `my_list[[4]]`, so the later check (`is.null(gde.gene[[i]])`) gives subscript out of bounds, not `TRUE` as expected.

If you use `my_list[4]` instead, you don't get this error:


```r
is.null(unlist(my_list[4]))
```

```
## [1] TRUE
```

This seemed like the simplest solution.

Tim

title: FindMarkers bug
body:
I noticed a bug in the `FindMarkers()` function where if any clusters had only 1 cell, this would cause an error (issue #33 might be related):

```r
dat <- readRDS("seurat_obj.Rdata")
WhichCells(dat, 40)  # an example cluster with only 1 cell
```
```
"CAGGTGCGTGCACTTA"
```
```r
FindMarkers(dat, ident.1 = 40)
```
```
Error in apply(object@data[genes.use, cells.1], 1, function(x) return(length(x[x >  :
  dim(X) must have a positive length
```

I believe this is because when the number of cells is 1, iterating over rows in `apply` fails because `dim(cells.1)` is `NULL`. The change I made just coerces the subset of cells that is iterated over by `apply` to a matrix to avoid this problem.

To me, the expected result of setting `min.cells` would be to skip any clusters where the total number of cells is less than `min.cells`, since you can't have more than `min.cells` cells expressing any gene if the total number of cells in the cluster is less than `min.cells`, so I also added an additional check for that. Finding markers for one cell also tends to take a really long time and doesn't really make that much sense, so I think it's good to be able to skip those clusters by setting `min.cells`.

Tim

title: Update to FindMarkers
body: The FindMarkers code has a useful line that allows a user to pass cell names, instead of an identity class, to the "ident.1" and "ident.2" parameters. As the code is currently written, if a user passes cell names, an error will be thrown because of "cells.1=WhichCells(object,ident.1)" before that useful line of code is ever reached. I have changed the order of the two lines and added an if/else to fix the bug.

title: New imputation strategies; Codes are faster.
body:
## Overview

| Functions | What's New |
| --- | --- |
| addImputedScore | additional imputation strategies |
| fit.gene.k | 10X faster; strict control of biological meanings |
| initial.mapping | 1X faster |
| refined.mapping | 17X faster |
| jackStraw | debug #5 |

---

Changes are imported from the extension repository: https://github.com/Puriney/honfleuR. If this PR were merged, `seurat` will have the new imputation strategies and improved running speed from 1X to 17X. 

As these modifications are exactly same as provided in `honfleuR`, the author could do the following convenient steps to try `honflueR` to see the improvements without changing your own codes. 

**1. Install `honflueR`**

``` r
require(devtools)
install_github("Puriney/honfleuR", subdir = "pkg")
```

**2. Try `honflueR`**

Referring to latest vignette here (https://github.com/Puriney/honfleuR/blob/bd171f0d2016f8f1200d4cf5d2fc3ece6ee26989/report/2016-01-31/2016-01-31-compare.pdf) to see how this PR improves seurat with maintaining original syntax, and without changing the entire codes design.

**3. Merge and enjoy**

title: Update seurat.R
body:
Small changes to jackStrawPlot: 
- changed the labeling strategy so that the facets are ordered from the first to the last PC (there was a problem with PC10 and higher appearing before PC1-9)
- added the ability to specify a PC range that does not start with 1 (would return an error before)

title: Improve bimodal model fitting speed and make un-biased scatter plot
body:
**Major Improvement**

12 times faster when calling `fit.gene.k` function to train the bimodal model of landmark gene. See result at this commit https://github.com/Puriney/seurat/commit/cea06de0a58799312d83adeb6dd75617728b9162 . 

**Minor Improvement**

Add transparent parameter for scatter plot when calling `dim.plot` function, as a way to get un-biased visualization effect. See result at this commit https://github.com/Puriney/seurat/commit/6c82851d9d6b129c6e6c700005dedb3010cb0c9d . 

**Code Review**
- `fit.gene.k.fast` function is saved in separated R source file, rather than editing your original code. 
- `pt.alpha` parameter is added to your original `dim.plot` function as it did not change a lot. 

**Git it a try**

``` R
install_github("Puriney/seurat")
```
